caption.langstring: Differentiation of the curriculum or learning goals
Individual learning needs, including those related to cognitive style
Accountability and educational standards re SEN
Alternative provision, including education otherwise (than at school) and home tuition
Switches and other technological aids to communication
Autistic spectrum disorder (ASD), including Asperger's syndrome
Autistic spectrum disorder (ASD), including Asperger's syndrome
Behaviour, emotional and social development needs
Strategies to improve motivation and concentration
Behaviour, emotional and social development needs
Blindness, low vision and visual impairment (VI)
Symbols and other pictorial aids to communication for pupils with severe or profound learning difficulties
Therapists addressing communication needs, including speech and language therapists
Differentiation of the curriculum or learning goals
Early Years Action and Early Years Action Plus
Alternative provision, including education otherwise (than at school) and home tuition
Pupil Referral Unit/PRU/social exclusion unit/secure unit
Special schools, including non-maintained and independent schools
Exclusion, including fixed term and permanent
Exclusion, including fixed term and permanent
Poverty and its impact on SEN
Refugees, including asylum seekers and newly arrived children
Gender issues in relation to SEN
Gender issues in relation to SEN
Haptic (touch) systems, including Braille and Moon
Individual learning needs, including those related to cognitive style
Early Years Action and Early Years Action Plus
SEN Code of Practice/Code of Practice
School Action and School Action Plus
Learning difficulties, including mild learning difficulties
Learning difficulties, including mild learning difficulties
Accountability and educational standards re SEN
Mobility and independence of the blind and visually impaired
Outreach, including integration support teachers/link teachers
Therapists addressing physical needs, including occupational therapists and physiotherapists
Poverty and its impact on SEN
Pupil Referral Unit/PRU/social exclusion unit/secure unit
Refugees, including asylum seekers and newly arrived children
SEN Code of Practice/Code of Practice
SEN partnerships, including SEN regional partnerships
SEN policies at school, local and regional levels
SEN policies at school, local and regional levels
School Action and School Action Plus
School psychology services, including child welfare services
Blindness, low vision and visual impairment (VI)
Haptic (touch) systems, including Braille and Moon
Mobility and independence of the blind and visually impaired
Signing systems including British Sign Language, for deaf/hearing impaired pupils
Therapists addressing sensory needs, including audiologists
Signing systems including British Sign Language, for deaf/hearing impaired pupils
Special needs assistants/learning support assistants/teaching assistants
Special schools, including non-maintained and independent schools
Strategies to improve motivation and concentration
Outreach, including integration support teachers/link teachers
SEN partnerships, including SEN regional partnerships
School psychology services, including child welfare services
Special needs assistants/learning support assistants/teaching assistants
Switches and other technological aids to communication
Symbols and other pictorial aids to communication for pupils with severe or profound learning difficulties
Therapists addressing communication needs, including speech and language therapists
Therapists addressing physical needs, including occupational therapists and physiotherapists
Therapists addressing sensory needs, including audiologists
1 combine clauses into complex sentences, using the comma effectively as a boundary signpost and checking for fluency and clarity, e.g. using nonfinite clauses;
1 combine information from various sources into one coherent document;
1 correct vowel choices, including: vowels with common alternative spellings, e.g. ay, ai, ae; unstressed vowels; the influence of vowels on other letters, e.g. doubling consonants, softening c;
1 experiment with different approaches to planning, drafting, proofreading and presenting writing, taking account of the time available;
Fitness of handwriting for different purposes
Presentational devices for different sorts of writing
1 extend their use and control of complex sentences by:
a recognising and using subordinate clauses;
b exploring the functions of subordinate clauses, e.g. relative clauses such as 'which I bought' or adverbial clauses such as 'having finished his lunch';
c deploying subordinate clauses in a variety of positions within the sentence;
1 know how to locate resources for a given task, and find relevant information in them, e.g. skimming, use of index, glossary, key words, hotlinks;
1 plan, draft, edit, revise, proofread and present a text with readers and purpose in mind;
1 reflect on the development of their abilities as speakers in a range of different contexts and identify areas for improvement;
1 reflect on the development of their abilities as speakers in a range of different contexts and identify areas for improvement;
1 review all aspects of spelling covered in Years 7 and 8 and continue to improve their spelling by applying knowledge of spelling conventions;
1 review and develop the meaning, clarity, organisation and impact of complex sentences in their own writing;
1 review and extend their own strategies for locating, appraising and extracting relevant information;
1 review their ability to write for a range of purposes and audiences, recognising strengths and identifying skills for further development;
1 review, consolidate and secure the spelling conventions covered in Year 7 which include:
1 use talk as a tool for clarifying ideas, e.g. by articulating problems or asking pertinent questions;
10 analyse the overall structure of a text to identify how key ideas are developed, e.g. through the organisation of the content and the patterns of language used;
10 comment on interpretations of the same text or idea in different media, using terms appropriate for critical analysis;
10 contribute to the organisation of group activity in ways that help to structure plans, solve problems and evaluate alternatives;
10 draw on analogies to known words, roots, derivations, word families, morphology and familiar spelling patterns;
10 explain the precise connections between ideas with clarity and an appropriate degree of formality;
10 explore differing attitudes to language, and identify characteristics of standard English that make it the dominant mode of public communication;
10 extend the range of prepositions and connectives used to indicate purpose, e.g. in order to, so that, or express reservations, e.g. although, unless, if;
10 identify and report the main points emerging from discussion, e.g. to agree a course of action including responsibilities and deadlines;
Group discussion: variety of activities & purposes
10 identify how media texts are tailored to suit their audience, and recognise that audience responses vary, e.g. popular websites;
10 identify the key alterations made to a text when it is changed from an informal to a formal text, e.g. change from first to third person, nominalisation, use of passive verbs;
10 organise and present information, selecting and synthesising appropriate material and guiding the reader clearly through the text, e.g. a technological process, an information leaflet;
10 organise texts in ways appropriate to their content, e.g. by chronology, priority, comparison, and signpost this clearly to the reader;
10 recognise how sentences are organised in a paragraph in which the content is not chronological, e.g. by comparison;
10 use talk to question, hypothesise, speculate,evaluate, solve problems and develop thinking about complex issues and ideas;
11 adopt a range of roles in discussion, including acting as spokesperson, and contribute in different ways such as promoting, opposing, exploring and questioning;
11 analyse how an author's standpoint can affect meaning in non-literary as well as literary texts;
Literary non-fiction: personal record & viewpoints on society
11 appreciate the impact of figurative language in texts;
11 explain complex ideas and information clearly, e.g. defining principles, explaining a scientific process;
11 identify words which pose a particular challenge and learn them by using mnemonics, multi-sensory re-inforcement and memorising critical features;
11 investigate the different ways familiar themes are explored and presented by different writers;
11 investigate ways English has changed over time and identify current trends of language change, e.g. word meanings;
11 make telling use of descriptive detail, e.g. eyewitness accounts, sports reports, travel writing;
11 recognise and build on other people's contributions;
11 recognise how print, sounds and still or moving images combine to create meaning;
Multimodal texts: how meaning is conveyed
11 recognise, evaluate and extend the skills and techniques they have developed through drama;
11 select and present information using detail, example, diagram and illustration as appropriate;
11 understand the main differences between standard English and dialectal variations, e.g subject-verb agreement, formation of past tense, adverbs and negatives, use of pronouns and prepositions;
11 vary the structure of sentences within paragraphs to lend pace, variety and emphasis;
12 analyse and discuss the use made of rhetorical devices in a text;
12 comment, using appropriate terminology on how writers convey setting, character and mood through word choice and sentence structure;
Using syntax to convey a range of meanings & effects
12 describe an event, process or situation, using language with an appropriate degree of formality, e.g. a school prospectus;
12 develop ideas and lines of thinking in continuous text and explain a process logically, highlighting the links between cause and effect;
12 exploit the potential of presentational devices when presenting information on paper or on screen, e.g. font size, text layout, bullet points;
Presentational devices for different sorts of writing
12 explore and use different degrees of formality in written and oral texts, e.g. formal speeches, informal journals;
12 organise ideas into a coherent sequence of paragraphs, introducing, developing and concluding them appropriately;
12 recognise how the degree of formality influences word choice;
12 take different roles in discussion, helping to develop ideas, seek consensus and report the main strands of thought;
12 use a range of drama techniques, including work in role, to explore issues, ideas and meanings e.g. by playing out hypotheses, by changing perspectives;
12 use exploratory, hypothetical and speculative talk as a way of researching ideas and expanding thinking;
Group discussion: variety of activities & purposes
12 use the quartiles of a dictionary and find words beyond the initial letter;
13 develop and compare different interpretations of scenes or plays by Shakespeare or other dramatists;
Plays: major dramatists other than Shakespeare
13 give instructions and directions which are specific, easy to follow and clearly sequenced;
13 identify, using appropriate terminology the way writers of non-fiction match language and organisation to their intentions, e.g. in campaighn material;
13 make effective use of a spellchecker, recognising where it might not be sufficient or appropriate.
13 present a case persuasively enough to gain the attention and influence the responses of a specified group of readers;
13 present a case persuasively, making selective use of evidence, using appropriate rhetorical devices and anticipating responses and objections;
13 read a substantial text (novel, play or work of one poet) revising and refining interpretations of subject matter, style and technique;
13 recognise some of the differences in sentence structure, vocabulary and tone between a modern English text and a text from another historical period;

13 reflect on their participation in drama and identify areas for their development of dramatic techniques, e.g. keep a reflective record of their contributions to dramatic improvisation and presentations;
13 review and develop their own reading skills, experiences and preferences, noting strengths and areas for development;
13 revise the stylistic conventions of the main types of fiction:
a Information, which maintains the use of the present tense and the third person, organises and links information clearly; incorporates examples
b Recount, maintains the use of past tense, clear chronology and temporal connectives;
c Explanation, maintains the use of the present tense and impersonal voice, and links points clearly;
d Instructions, which are helpfully sequenced and signposted, deploy imperative verbs and provide clear guidance;
e Persuasion, emphasises key points and articulates logical links in the argument;
f Discursive writing, which signposts the organisation of contrasting points and clarifies the viewpoint;
13 understand the implications when a word is in quotation marks or is used ironically;
Speech marks, inverted commas & quotation marks
13 work together logically and methodically to solve problems, make deductions, share, test and evaluate ideas;
14 acknowledge other people's views, justifying or modifying their own views in the light of what others say;
14 analyse the language, form and dramatic impact of scenes and plays by published dramatists;
Meanings: different perspectives on individuals, community, society
Meanings: portrayal of ideas, values & emotions
Meanings: whole texts & connections between parts
14 collect and comment on examples of language change, e.g. new words associated with electronic communication and ICT.
14 convey action, character, atmosphere and tension when scripting and performing plays;
14 define and deploy words with precision, including their exact implication in context;
14 describe an object, person or setting in a way that includes relevant details and is accurate and evocative;
14 develop and signpost arguments in ways that make the logic clear to the reader;
14 develop the dramatic techniques that enable them to create and sustain a variety of roles;
14 draw on their knowledge of other languages to identify some of the differences and similarities between those languages and English.
14 make a counter-argument to a view that has been expressed, addressing weaknesses in the argument and offering alternatives;
14 recognise and use stylistic conventions of the main forms of writing used in subjects, e.g. science report, book review;
14 recognise how writers' language choices can enhance meaning, e.g. repetition, emotive vocabulary, varied sentence structure or line length, sound effects;
Using syntax to convey a range of meanings & effects
14 recognise the conventions of some common literary forms, e.g. sonnet, and genres, e.g. Gothic horror, and explore how a particular text adheres to or deviates from established conventions;
15 develop drama techniques to explore in role a variety of situations and texts or respond to stimuli;
15 explore and develop ideas, issues and relationships through work in role;
15 express a personal view, adding persuasive emphasis to key points, e.g. by reiteration, exaggeration, repetition, use of rhetorical questions;
15 extend their understanding of literary heritage by relating major writers to their historical context, and explaining their appeal over time;
Fiction: English literary heritage: novels & short stories
15 give written advice which offers alternatives and takes account of the possible consequences, e.g. money management for young people;
15 identify links between literary heritage texts and their times, e.g. the social context of a nineteenth century novel;
Fiction: English literary heritage: novels & short stories
15 offer general advice or guidelines for action adopting an impersonal style to suggest impartiality and authority;
15 trace the ways in which a writer structures a text to prepare a reader for the ending, and comment on the effectiveness of the ending;
15 use a dictionary and a thesaurus with speed and skill;
15 vary the formality of language in speech and writing to suit different circumstances;
15 write critical evaluations of performances they have seen or in which they have participated, identifying the contributions of the writer, director and actors.
16 analyse ways in which different cultural contexts and traditions have influenced language and style, e.g. black British poetry, Irish short stories;
16 collaborate in, and evaluate, the presentation of dramatic performances, scripted and unscripted, which explore character, relationships and issues;
16 distinguish between the attitudes and assumptions of characters and those of the author;
16 find and use different ways to validate an argument, e.g. statistical evidence, exemplification, testimony;
16 investigate differences between spoken and written language structures, e.g. hesitation in speech;
16 present a balanced analysis of a situation, text, issue or set of ideas, taking into account a range of evidence and opinions;
16 recognise how texts refer to and reflect the culture in which they were produced, e.g. in their evocation of place and values.
Meanings: different perspectives on individuals, community, society
Meanings: portrayal of ideas, values & emotions
16 weigh different viewpoints and present a balanced analysis of an event or issue, e.g. an environmental issue or historical investigation;
16 work collaboratively to devise and present scripted and unscripted pieces, which maintain the attention of an audience;
16 work out the meaning of unknown words using context, etymology, morphology, compound patterns and other qualities such as onomatopoeia;
17 cite specific and relevant textual evidence to justify critical judgements about texts.
17 compare the themes and styles of two or more poets;
17 extend their spoken repertoire by experimenting with language in different roles and dramatic contexts;
17 integrate evidence into writing to support analysis or conclusions, e.g. data, quotation;
17 read a range of recent fiction texts independently as the basis for developing critical reflection and personal response, e.g. sharing views, keeping a reading journal;
17 understand and have the terminology to describe the role of word classes, e.g. preposition, auxiliary verb;
17 use standard English consistently in formal situations and in writing;
17 write informal advice, anticipating the needs, interests and views of the intended reader, e.g. how to make the most of an opportunity;
18 develop drama techniques and strategies for anticipating, visualising and problem-solving in different learning contexts;
18 discuss a substantial prose text, sharing perceptions, negotiating common readings and accounting for differences of view.
Meanings: portrayal of ideas, values & emotions
18 give a considered response to a play, as script, on screen or in performance, focusing on interpretation of action, character and event;
18 identify criteria for evaluating a particular situation, object or event, present findings fairly and give a personal view;
18 identify specific ways sentence structure and punctuation are different in older texts.
18 understand and use correctly terms of qualification e.g. fully, slightly, similarly, mostly, and comparison, e.g. less, fewer, more, most, ...-er /-est;
18 write a critical review of a substantial text, taking account of the context in which it was written and the likely impact on its intended readers.
19 explore how form contributes to meaning in poems from different times and cultures, e.g. story telling in ballads;
19 investigate and apply lexical patterns, e.g. adding -ify to an adjective to create a verb;
19 reflect on and evaluate their own presentations and those of others.
19 write reflectively about a text, taking account of the needs of others who might read it.
2 collect, select and assemble ideas in a suitable planning format, e.g. flow chart, list, star chart;
Writing as an aid to memory & understanding
2 expand nouns and noun phrases e.g. by using a prepositional phrase;
2 explore the impact of a variety of sentence structures, e.g. recognising when it is effective to use short direct sentences;
Using syntax to convey a range of meanings & effects
2 pluralisation, including -es endings and words ending in y, f and vowels;
2 re-read work to anticipate the effect on the reader and revise style and structure, as well as accuracy, with this in mind;
2 record, develop and evaluate ideas through writing, e.g. essays, journals;
Writing as an aid to memory & understanding
2 recount a story, anecdote or experience, and consider how this differs from written narrative;
2 spell accurately all high-frequency words and new terms from all subject areas;
2 synthesise information from a range of sources, shaping material to meet the reader's needs;
2 tell a story, recount an experience or develop an idea, choosing and changing the mood, tone and pace of delivery for particular effect;
2 undertake independent research using a range of reading strategies, applying their knowledge of how texts and ICT databases are organised and acknowledging sources;
Distinguishing subjectivity, objectivity, fact, opinion & bias in information
Identifying characteristic features of printed & ICT-based information
2 use appropriate reading strategies to extract particular information, e.g. highlighting, scanning;
2 use standard English to explain, explore or justify an idea;
2 use the full range of punctuation to clarify and emphasise meaning for a reader;
Punctuation: to signal sentence structure & help the reader
20 expand the range of link words and phrases used to signpost texts, including links of time (then, later, meanwhile) and cause (so, because, since);
20 explore the notion of literary heritage and understand why some texts have been particularly inluential or significant.
Fiction: English literary heritage: novels & short stories
21 read accurately, and use correctly, vocabulary which relates to key concepts in each subject, distinguishing between everyday uses of words and their subject specific use, e.g. energy, resistance;
22 draw links between words in different languages, e.g. Haus - house; femme - feminine.
3 compare and contrast the ways information is presented in different forms, e.g. web page, diagrams, prose;
Identifying characteristic features of printed & ICT-based information
3 develop interview techniques which include planning a series of linked questions, helping the respondent to give useful answers, responding to and extending the responses;
3 increase the speed and accuracy of note-making skills and use notes for re-presenting information for specific purposes;
3 investigate lexical patterns in new vocabulary;
3 make a formal presentation in standard English, using appropriate rhetorical devices;
3 make good use of the full range of punctuation, including colons and semi-colons
3 make notes in different ways, choosing a form which suits the purpose, e.g. diagrammatic notes, making notes during a video, abbreviating for speed and ease of retrieval;
Writing as an aid to memory & understanding
3 produce formal essays in standard English within a specified time, writing fluently and legibly and maintaining technical accuracy when writing at speed;
3 recognise their strengths as spellers, identify areas where they need to improve and use appropriate strategies to eliminate persistent errors;
3 tailor the structure, vocabulary and delivery of a talk or presentation so that listeners can follow it;
3 use punctuation to clarify meaning, particularly at the boundaries between sentences and clauses;
Punctuation: to signal sentence structure & help the reader
3 use writing for thinking and learning by recording ideas as they develop to aid reflection and problem solving;
Writing as an aid to memory & understanding
3 use writing to explore and develop ideas, e.g. journals, brainstorming techniques and mental mapping activities;
Writing as an aid to memory & understanding
3 word endings, including vowel suffixes such as -ing; consonant suffixes such as -ful; modifying words ending in y or e; making choices between similar endings such as -cian, -sion and -tion;
3 write with differing degrees of formality, relating vocabulary and grammar to context, e.g. using the active or passive voice;
4 choose, use and evaluate a range of presentational devices, on paper and on screen;
Presentational devices for different sorts of writing
4 develop a fluent, legible handwriting style which can be maintained under time pressure;
Fitness of handwriting for different purposes
4 evaluate the relevance, reliability and validity of information available through print, ICT and other media sources;
Evaluating usefulness & relevance of texts & information
4 explore the effects of changes in tense, e.g. past to present for vividness;
Using syntax to convey a range of meanings & effects
4 give clear answers, instructions or explanations that are helpfully sequenced, linked and supported by gesture or other visual aid;
4 integrate speech, reference and quotation effectively into what they write;
4 keep tense usage consistent, and manage changes of tense so that meaning is clear;
4 learn complex polysyllabic words and unfamiliar words which do not conform to regular patterns;
4 make brief, clearly-organised notes of key points for later use;
4 prefixes, including antonym prefixes, e.g. ir-, un-;
4 provide an explanation or commentary which links words with actions or images, e.g. a sports commentary or talking to a sequence of images;
4 reflect on and evaluate their own skills, strategies and successes as listeners in a variety of contexts;
4 review the legibility and neatness of their handwriting and set personal targets to improve presentation, using a range of presentational devices, on paper and on screen;
Fitness of handwriting for different purposes
Presentational devices for different sorts of writing
4 review their developing skills as active, critical readers who search for meaning using a range of reading strategies;
4a address personal difficulties with words by experimenting with different ways of learning and remembering difficult spellings, e.g. mnemonics
4b address personal difficulties with words by applying knowledge of word origins, families and morphology
4c address personal difficulties with words by identifying common spelling patterns and conventions in their growing vocabulary
5 appraise the value and relevance of information found and acknowledge sources;
5 ask questions to clarify understanding and refine ideas;
5 compare different points of view that have been expressed, identifying and evaluating differences and similarities;
5 develop the use of commentary and description in narrative, e.g. by addressing the reader directly;
5 evaluate their ability to shape ideas rapidly into cohesive paragraphs;
5 evaluate their own critical writing about texts;
5 explore different ways of opening, structuring and ending narratives and experiment with narrative perspective, e.g. multiple narration;
5 make use of different kinds of dictionary, thesaurus and spell checker;
5 promote, justify or defend a point of view using supporting evidence, example and illustration which are linked back to the main argument;
5 recognise and exploit the use of conditionals and modal verbs when speculating, hypothesising or discussing possibilities;
5 secure the spelling of key terms and new words from across the curriculum;
5 structure a story with an arresting opening, a developing plot, a complication, a crisis and a satisfying resolution;
5 the spellings of high-frequency words including common homophones;
5 trace the development of themes, values or ideas in texts;
Meanings: portrayal of ideas, values & emotions
5 use the active or the passive voice to suit purpose;
6 adopt active reading approaches to engage with and make sense of texts, e.g. visualising, predicting, empathising and relating to own experience;
6 analyse bias, e.g. through the use of deliberate ambiguity, omission, abuse of evidence;
6 comment on the authorial perspectives offered in texts on individuals, community and society in texts from different cultures;
Meanings: different perspectives on individuals, community, society
Meanings: portrayal of ideas, values & emotions
6 compare and use different ways of opening, developing, linking and completing paragraphs;
6 devise their own ways to improve their spelling, building on strategies from Year 7 including:
a maintaining a personal record of spelling difficulties and development;
b applying spelling rules and recognising exceptions;
c using dictionaries and spellcheckers where appropriate;
f drawing on word structures, families and derivations;
6 experiment with figurative language in conveying a sense of character and setting;
6 exploit the creative and aesthetic features of language in non-literary texts, e.g. the use of figurative language or the cadence of sentences;

6 explore and compare different methods of grouping sentences into paragraphs of continuous text that are clearly focused and well developed, e.g. by chronology, comparison or through adding exemplification;
6 know and use the terms that are useful for analysing language e.g. type of phrase or clause, conditional verb;
6 listen for and recall the main points of a talk, reading or television programme, reflecting on what has been heard to ask searching questions, make comments or challenge the views expressed;
6 portray character, directly and indirectly, through description, dialogue and action;
6 recognise and remedy ambiguity in sentences, e.g. unclear use of pronouns;
6 recognise bias and objectivity, distinguishing facts from hypotheses, theories or opinions;
Distinguishing subjectivity, objectivity, fact, opinion & bias in information
6 recognise their own skills, strategies and responses as listeners in different situations, e.g. to lyrics, to directions, to information;
6 the use of the apostrophe including: omissions; the possessive apostrophe; apostrophising plurals, e.g.ladies' coats, and words ending in s; the exception of possessive pronouns;
7 analyse and exploit the stylistic conventions of the main text types, e.g. parody;
7 answer questions pertinently, drawing on relevant evidence or reasons;
7 compare the presentation of ideas, values or emotions in related or contrasting texts;
7 develop different ways of linking paragraphs, using a range of strategies to improve cohesion and coherence, e.g. choice of connectives, reference back, linking phrases;
7 experiment with different language choices to imply meaning and to establish the tone of a piece, e.g. ironic, indignant;
7 explore how non-fiction texts can convey information or ideas in amusing or entertaining ways;
7 identify the main points, processes or ideas in a text and how they are sequenced and developed by the writer;
7 identify the underlying themes, implications and issues raised by a talk, reading or programme;
7 identify the ways implied and explicit meanings are conveyed in different texts, e.g. irony, satire;
7 listen for a specific purpose, paying sustained attention and selecting for comment or question that which is relevant to the agreed focus;
7 recognise layers of meaning in the writer's choice of words, e.g. connotation, implied meaning, different types or multiple meanings;
7 review and develop their ability to:
a recognise links between words related by word families and roots;
b work out the meaning of unknown words using context, syntax, etymology, morphology and other factors;
c understand and explain exactly what words mean in particular contexts;
7 the spellings of key words in each subject.
7 use a range of narrative devices to involve the reader, e.g. withholding information;
Using syntax to convey a range of meanings & effects
7 use speech punctuation accurately to integrate speech into larger sentences.
Speech marks, inverted commas & quotation marks
8 analyse how media texts influence and are influenced by readers, e.g. interactive programmes, selection of news items;
Multimodal texts: how meaning is conveyed
8 develop an imaginative or unusual treatment of familiar material or established conventions, e.g. updating traditional tales;
8 experiment with the visual and sound effects of language, including the use of imagery, alliteration, rhythm and rhyme;
8 identify the main methods used by presenters to explain, persuade, amuse or argue a case, e.g. emotive vocabulary, verbal humour;
Using syntax to convey a range of meanings & effects
8 infer and deduce meanings using evidence in the text, identifying where and how meanings are implied;
Distinguishing subjectivity, objectivity, fact, opinion & bias in information
8 investigate how meanings are changed when information is presented in different forms or transposed into different media;
Meanings: effects of adaptation of texts to different media
8 investigate the organisation and conventions of ICT texts, e.g. CD-ROM, e-mail, web pages;

8 know and use effectively the vocabulary, sentence grammar and stylistic conventions of the writing forms featured in specific subjects during the current year, e.g. scientific investigation, historical analysis;
8 recognise and record personal errors, corrections, investigations, conventions, exceptions and new vocabulary;
8 recognise how lines of thought are developed and signposted through the use of connectives, e.g. nonetheless, consequently, furthermore;
8 recognise the cues to start a new paragraph and use the first sentence effectively to orientate the reader, e.g. when there is a shift of topic, viewpoint or time;
8 recognise the range of ways in which messages are conveyed, e.g. tone, emphasis, status of speaker.
8 review the contributions they have made to recent discussions, recognising their strengths and identifying areas for development;
Group discussion: evaluating own & others' contributions
8 understand and use key terms that help to describe and analyse language, e.g. word class, noun phrase, subordinate clause, syntax, conditional;
8 write within the discipline of different poetic forms, exploring how form contributes to meaning, e.g. different types of sonnet;
9 adapt the stylistic conventions of the main non-fiction text types to fit different audiences and purposes, e.g. advertisements, documentaries, editorials;
9 appreciate the precise meaning of specialist vocabulary for each school subject, and use specialist terms aptly in their own writing;
9 compare themes and styles of two writers from different times;
9 discuss and evaluate conflicting evidence to arrive at a considered viewpoint;
9 distinguish between the views of the writer and those expressed by others in the text, e.g. the narrator, quoted experts, characters;
Meanings: different perspectives on individuals, community, society
Meanings: portrayal of ideas, values & emotions
9 experiment with presenting similar material in different forms and styles of poetry;
9 identify the main point in a paragraph, and how the supporting information relates to it, e.g. as illustration;
9 integrate diverse information into a coherent and comprehensive account;
9 make links between their reading of fiction, plays and poetry and the choices they make as writers;
9 recognise how texts are shaped by the technology they use, e.g. the use of sound and image in a computer animation.
9 recognise the way familiar spoken texts, e.g. directions, explanations, are organised and identify their typical features, e.g. of vocabulary or tone;
9 reflect on their individual strengths as contributors to group talk and identify points and opportunities for development;
Group discussion: evaluating own & others' contributions
9 sound out words phonemically and by syllables;
9 write sustained standard English with the formality suited to reader and purpose;
16 present a balanced analysis of a situation, text, issue or set of ideas, taking into account a range of evidence and opinions;
17 cite specific and relevant textual evidence to justify critical judgements about texts.
Distinguishing subjectivity, objectivity, fact, opinion & bias in information
11 recognise, evaluate and extend the skills and techniques they have developed through drama;
12 use a range of drama techniques, including work in role, to explore issues, ideas and meanings e.g. by playing out hypotheses, by changing perspectives;
13 develop and compare different interpretations of scenes or plays by Shakespeare or other dramatists;
14 convey action, character, atmosphere and tension when scripting and performing plays;
15 write critical evaluations of performances they have seen or in which they have participated, identifying the contributions of the writer, director and actors.
15 develop drama techniques to explore in role a variety of situations and texts or respond to stimuli;
16 work collaboratively to devise and present scripted and unscripted pieces, which maintain the attention of an audience;
17 extend their spoken repertoire by experimenting with language in different roles and dramatic contexts;
18 develop drama techniques and strategies for anticipating, visualising and problem-solving in different learning contexts;
19 reflect on and evaluate their own presentations and those of others.

13 reflect on their participation in drama and identify areas for their development of dramatic techniques, e.g. keep a reflective record of their contributions to dramatic improvisation and presentations;
14 develop the dramatic techniques that enable them to create and sustain a variety of roles;
15 explore and develop ideas, issues and relationships through work in role;
16 collaborate in, and evaluate, the presentation of dramatic performances, scripted and unscripted, which explore character, relationships and issues;
Evaluating usefulness & relevance of texts & information
Fiction: English literary heritage: novels & short stories
Fitness of handwriting for different purposes
10 contribute to the organisation of group activity in ways that help to structure plans, solve problems and evaluate alternatives;
8 review the contributions they have made to recent discussions, recognising their strengths and identifying areas for development;
9 discuss and evaluate conflicting evidence to arrive at a considered viewpoint;
10 use talk to question, hypothesise, speculate,evaluate, solve problems and develop thinking about complex issues and ideas;
11 recognise and build on other people's contributions;
12 take different roles in discussion, helping to develop ideas, seek consensus and report the main strands of thought;
9 reflect on their individual strengths as contributors to group talk and identify points and opportunities for development;
10 identify and report the main points emerging from discussion, e.g. to agree a course of action including responsibilities and deadlines;
11 adopt a range of roles in discussion, including acting as spokesperson, and contribute in different ways such as promoting, opposing, exploring and questioning;
12 use exploratory, hypothetical and speculative talk as a way of researching ideas and expanding thinking;
13 work together logically and methodically to solve problems, make deductions, share, test and evaluate ideas;
14 acknowledge other people's views, justifying or modifying their own views in the light of what others say;

Group discussion: variety of activities & purposes

5 explore different ways of opening, structuring and ending narratives and experiment with narrative perspective, e.g. multiple narration;
6 exploit the creative and aesthetic features of language in non-literary texts, e.g. the use of figurative language or the cadence of sentences;
7 explore how non-fiction texts can convey information or ideas in amusing or entertaining ways;
8 write within the discipline of different poetic forms, exploring how form contributes to meaning, e.g. different types of sonnet;
10 explain the precise connections between ideas with clarity and an appropriate degree of formality;
11 make telling use of descriptive detail, e.g. eyewitness accounts, sports reports, travel writing;
12 exploit the potential of presentational devices when presenting information on paper or on screen, e.g. font size, text layout, bullet points;
9 integrate diverse information into a coherent and comprehensive account;
6 listen for and recall the main points of a talk, reading or television programme, reflecting on what has been heard to ask searching questions, make comments or challenge the views expressed;
7 answer questions pertinently, drawing on relevant evidence or reasons;
8 identify the main methods used by presenters to explain, persuade, amuse or argue a case, e.g. emotive vocabulary, verbal humour;
9 recognise the way familiar spoken texts, e.g. directions, explanations, are organised and identify their typical features, e.g. of vocabulary or tone;
4 reflect on and evaluate their own skills, strategies and successes as listeners in a variety of contexts;
5 compare different points of view that have been expressed, identifying and evaluating differences and similarities;
6 analyse bias, e.g. through the use of deliberate ambiguity, omission, abuse of evidence;
7 identify the underlying themes, implications and issues raised by a talk, reading or programme;
6 recognise their own skills, strategies and responses as listeners in different situations, e.g. to lyrics, to directions, to information;
7 listen for a specific purpose, paying sustained attention and selecting for comment or question that which is relevant to the agreed focus;
8 recognise the range of ways in which messages are conveyed, e.g. tone, emphasis, status of speaker.

Meanings: different perspectives on individuals, community, society
Meanings: effects of adaptation of texts to different media

10 recognise how sentences are organised in a paragraph in which the content is not chronological, e.g. by comparison;
11 vary the structure of sentences within paragraphs to lend pace, variety and emphasis;
12 organise ideas into a coherent sequence of paragraphs, introducing, developing and concluding them appropriately;
8 recognise the cues to start a new paragraph and use the first sentence effectively to orientate the reader, e.g. when there is a shift of topic, viewpoint or time;
9 identify the main point in a paragraph, and how the supporting information relates to it, e.g. as illustration;
5 evaluate their ability to shape ideas rapidly into cohesive paragraphs;
6 compare and use different ways of opening, developing, linking and completing paragraphs;

6 explore and compare different methods of grouping sentences into paragraphs of continuous text that are clearly focused and well developed, e.g. by chronology, comparison or through adding exemplification;
7 develop different ways of linking paragraphs, using a range of strategies to improve cohesion and coherence, e.g. choice of connectives, reference back, linking phrases;
13 present a case persuasively enough to gain the attention and influence the responses of a specified group of readers;
14 make a counter-argument to a view that has been expressed, addressing weaknesses in the argument and offering alternatives;
15 offer general advice or guidelines for action adopting an impersonal style to suggest impartiality and authority;
1 review their ability to write for a range of purposes and audiences, recognising strengths and identifying skills for further development;
2 record, develop and evaluate ideas through writing, e.g. essays, journals;
3 produce formal essays in standard English within a specified time, writing fluently and legibly and maintaining technical accuracy when writing at speed;
4 choose, use and evaluate a range of presentational devices, on paper and on screen;
1 plan, draft, edit, revise, proofread and present a text with readers and purpose in mind;
2 collect, select and assemble ideas in a suitable planning format, e.g. flow chart, list, star chart;
3 use writing to explore and develop ideas, e.g. journals, brainstorming techniques and mental mapping activities;
4 review the legibility and neatness of their handwriting and set personal targets to improve presentation, using a range of presentational devices, on paper and on screen;
1 experiment with different approaches to planning, drafting, proofreading and presenting writing, taking account of the time available;
2 re-read work to anticipate the effect on the reader and revise style and structure, as well as accuracy, with this in mind;
3 use writing for thinking and learning by recording ideas as they develop to aid reflection and problem solving;
4 develop a fluent, legible handwriting style which can be maintained under time pressure;

Presentational devices for different sorts of writing
Punctuation: to signal sentence structure & help the reader
4 review their developing skills as active, critical readers who search for meaning using a range of reading strategies;
5 trace the development of themes, values or ideas in texts;
6 recognise bias and objectivity, distinguishing facts from hypotheses, theories or opinions;
7 identify the ways implied and explicit meanings are conveyed in different texts, e.g. irony, satire;
8 investigate how meanings are changed when information is presented in different forms or transposed into different media;
9 recognise how texts are shaped by the technology they use, e.g. the use of sound and image in a computer animation.
5 evaluate their own critical writing about texts;
6 comment on the authorial perspectives offered in texts on individuals, community and society in texts from different cultures;
7 compare the presentation of ideas, values or emotions in related or contrasting texts;
8 analyse how media texts influence and are influenced by readers, e.g. interactive programmes, selection of news items;
10 identify how media texts are tailored to suit their audience, and recognise that audience responses vary, e.g. popular websites;
11 recognise how print, sounds and still or moving images combine to create meaning;
6 adopt active reading approaches to engage with and make sense of texts, e.g. visualising, predicting, empathising and relating to own experience;
7 identify the main points, processes or ideas in a text and how they are sequenced and developed by the writer;
8 infer and deduce meanings using evidence in the text, identifying where and how meanings are implied;
9 distinguish between the views of the writer and those expressed by others in the text, e.g. the narrator, quoted experts, characters;
1 know how to locate resources for a given task, and find relevant information in them, e.g. skimming, use of index, glossary, key words, hotlinks;
2 use appropriate reading strategies to extract particular information, e.g. highlighting, scanning;
3 compare and contrast the ways information is presented in different forms, e.g. web page, diagrams, prose;
4 make brief, clearly-organised notes of key points for later use;
5 appraise the value and relevance of information found and acknowledge sources;
1 review and extend their own strategies for locating, appraising and extracting relevant information;
2 synthesise information from a range of sources, shaping material to meet the reader's needs;
3 increase the speed and accuracy of note-making skills and use notes for re-presenting information for specific purposes;
4 evaluate the relevance, reliability and validity of information available through print, ICT and other media sources;
1 combine information from various sources into one coherent document;
2 undertake independent research using a range of reading strategies, applying their knowledge of how texts and ICT databases are organised and acknowledging sources;
3 make notes in different ways, choosing a form which suits the purpose, e.g. diagrammatic notes, making notes during a video, abbreviating for speed and ease of retrieval;
1 extend their use and control of complex sentences by:
2 expand nouns and noun phrases e.g. by using a prepositional phrase;
3 use punctuation to clarify meaning, particularly at the boundaries between sentences and clauses;
4 keep tense usage consistent, and manage changes of tense so that meaning is clear;
5 use the active or the passive voice to suit purpose;
6 recognise and remedy ambiguity in sentences, e.g. unclear use of pronouns;
7 use speech punctuation accurately to integrate speech into larger sentences.
1 review and develop the meaning, clarity, organisation and impact of complex sentences in their own writing;
2 use the full range of punctuation to clarify and emphasise meaning for a reader;
3 write with differing degrees of formality, relating vocabulary and grammar to context, e.g. using the active or passive voice;
4 integrate speech, reference and quotation effectively into what they write;
1 combine clauses into complex sentences, using the comma effectively as a boundary signpost and checking for fluency and clarity, e.g. using nonfinite clauses;
2 explore the impact of a variety of sentence structures, e.g. recognising when it is effective to use short direct sentences;
3 make good use of the full range of punctuation, including colons and semi-colons
4 explore the effects of changes in tense, e.g. past to present for vividness;
5 recognise and exploit the use of conditionals and modal verbs when speculating, hypothesising or discussing possibilities;
1 reflect on the development of their abilities as speakers in a range of different contexts and identify areas for improvement;
2 tell a story, recount an experience or develop an idea, choosing and changing the mood, tone and pace of delivery for particular effect;
3 make a formal presentation in standard English, using appropriate rhetorical devices;
4 provide an explanation or commentary which links words with actions or images, e.g. a sports commentary or talking to a sequence of images;
5 ask questions to clarify understanding and refine ideas;
1 use talk as a tool for clarifying ideas, e.g. by articulating problems or asking pertinent questions;
2 recount a story, anecdote or experience, and consider how this differs from written narrative;
3 tailor the structure, vocabulary and delivery of a talk or presentation so that listeners can follow it;
4 give clear answers, instructions or explanations that are helpfully sequenced, linked and supported by gesture or other visual aid;
5 promote, justify or defend a point of view using supporting evidence, example and illustration which are linked back to the main argument;
1 reflect on the development of their abilities as speakers in a range of different contexts and identify areas for improvement;
2 use standard English to explain, explore or justify an idea;
3 develop interview techniques which include planning a series of linked questions, helping the respondent to give useful answers, responding to and extending the responses;
Speech marks, inverted commas & quotation marks
1 review, consolidate and secure the spelling conventions covered in Year 7 which include:
3 investigate lexical patterns in new vocabulary;
4 learn complex polysyllabic words and unfamiliar words which do not conform to regular patterns;
5 secure the spelling of key terms and new words from across the curriculum;
1 review all aspects of spelling covered in Years 7 and 8 and continue to improve their spelling by applying knowledge of spelling conventions;
2 spell accurately all high-frequency words and new terms from all subject areas;
1 correct vowel choices, including: vowels with common alternative spellings, e.g. ay, ai, ae; unstressed vowels; the influence of vowels on other letters, e.g. doubling consonants, softening c;
2 pluralisation, including -es endings and words ending in y, f and vowels;
3 word endings, including vowel suffixes such as -ing; consonant suffixes such as -ful; modifying words ending in y or e; making choices between similar endings such as -cian, -sion and -tion;
4 prefixes, including antonym prefixes, e.g. ir-, un-;
5 the spellings of high-frequency words including common homophones;
6 the use of the apostrophe including: omissions; the possessive apostrophe; apostrophising plurals, e.g.ladies' coats, and words ending in s; the exception of possessive pronouns;
7 the spellings of key words in each subject.
3 recognise their strengths as spellers, identify areas where they need to improve and use appropriate strategies to eliminate persistent errors;
4a address personal difficulties with words by experimenting with different ways of learning and remembering difficult spellings, e.g. mnemonics
4b address personal difficulties with words by applying knowledge of word origins, families and morphology
4c address personal difficulties with words by identifying common spelling patterns and conventions in their growing vocabulary
5 make use of different kinds of dictionary, thesaurus and spell checker;
6 devise their own ways to improve their spelling, building on strategies from Year 7 including:
10 draw on analogies to known words, roots, derivations, word families, morphology and familiar spelling patterns;
11 identify words which pose a particular challenge and learn them by using mnemonics, multi-sensory re-inforcement and memorising critical features;
12 use the quartiles of a dictionary and find words beyond the initial letter;
13 make effective use of a spellchecker, recognising where it might not be sufficient or appropriate.
8 recognise and record personal errors, corrections, investigations, conventions, exceptions and new vocabulary;
9 sound out words phonemically and by syllables;
15 vary the formality of language in speech and writing to suit different circumstances;
16 investigate differences between spoken and written language structures, e.g. hesitation in speech;
17 use standard English consistently in formal situations and in writing;
18 identify specific ways sentence structure and punctuation are different in older texts.
11 understand the main differences between standard English and dialectal variations, e.g subject-verb agreement, formation of past tense, adverbs and negatives, use of pronouns and prepositions;
12 explore and use different degrees of formality in written and oral texts, e.g. formal speeches, informal journals;
13 recognise some of the differences in sentence structure, vocabulary and tone between a modern English text and a text from another historical period;
14 draw on their knowledge of other languages to identify some of the differences and similarities between those languages and English.
10 explore differing attitudes to language, and identify characteristics of standard English that make it the dominant mode of public communication;
11 investigate ways English has changed over time and identify current trends of language change, e.g. word meanings;
9 write sustained standard English with the formality suited to reader and purpose;
13 review and develop their own reading skills, experiences and preferences, noting strengths and areas for development;
14 analyse the language, form and dramatic impact of scenes and plays by published dramatists;
15 extend their understanding of literary heritage by relating major writers to their historical context, and explaining their appeal over time;
16 analyse ways in which different cultural contexts and traditions have influenced language and style, e.g. black British poetry, Irish short stories;
17 compare the themes and styles of two or more poets;
18 discuss a substantial prose text, sharing perceptions, negotiating common readings and accounting for differences of view.
12 record and review the development of their independent reading, and identify ways of increasing its scope and challenge;
13 read a substantial text (novel, play or work of one poet) revising and refining interpretations of subject matter, style and technique;
14 recognise the conventions of some common literary forms, e.g. sonnet, and genres, e.g. Gothic horror, and explore how a particular text adheres to or deviates from established conventions;
15 identify links between literary heritage texts and their times, e.g. the social context of a nineteenth century novel;
16 recognise how texts refer to and reflect the culture in which they were produced, e.g. in their evocation of place and values.
17 read a range of recent fiction texts independently as the basis for developing critical reflection and personal response, e.g. sharing views, keeping a reading journal;
18 give a considered response to a play, as script, on screen or in performance, focusing on interpretation of action, character and event;
19 explore how form contributes to meaning in poems from different times and cultures, e.g. story telling in ballads;
20 explore the notion of literary heritage and understand why some texts have been particularly inluential or significant.
13 revise the stylistic conventions of the main types of fiction:
14 recognise and use stylistic conventions of the main forms of writing used in subjects, e.g. science report, book review;
7 analyse and exploit the stylistic conventions of the main text types, e.g. parody;
8 investigate the organisation and conventions of ICT texts, e.g. CD-ROM, e-mail, web pages;
10 identify the key alterations made to a text when it is changed from an informal to a formal text, e.g. change from first to third person, nominalisation, use of passive verbs;

8 know and use effectively the vocabulary, sentence grammar and stylistic conventions of the writing forms featured in specific subjects during the current year, e.g. scientific investigation, historical analysis;
9 adapt the stylistic conventions of the main non-fiction text types to fit different audiences and purposes, e.g. advertisements, documentaries, editorials;
10 analyse the overall structure of a text to identify how key ideas are developed, e.g. through the organisation of the content and the patterns of language used;
11 investigate the different ways familiar themes are explored and presented by different writers;
10 comment on interpretations of the same text or idea in different media, using terms appropriate for critical analysis;
11 analyse how an author's standpoint can affect meaning in non-literary as well as literary texts;
12 analyse and discuss the use made of rhetorical devices in a text;
9 compare themes and styles of two writers from different times;
12 comment, using appropriate terminology on how writers convey setting, character and mood through word choice and sentence structure;
13 identify, using appropriate terminology the way writers of non-fiction match language and organisation to their intentions, e.g. in campaighn material;
14 recognise how writers' language choices can enhance meaning, e.g. repetition, emotive vocabulary, varied sentence structure or line length, sound effects;
15 trace the ways in which a writer structures a text to prepare a reader for the ending, and comment on the effectiveness of the ending;
16 distinguish between the attitudes and assumptions of characters and those of the author;
Using syntax to convey a range of meanings & effects
6 know and use the terms that are useful for analysing language e.g. type of phrase or clause, conditional verb;
7 recognise layers of meaning in the writer's choice of words, e.g. connotation, implied meaning, different types or multiple meanings;
8 recognise how lines of thought are developed and signposted through the use of connectives, e.g. nonetheless, consequently, furthermore;
14 define and deploy words with precision, including their exact implication in context;
15 use a dictionary and a thesaurus with speed and skill;
16 work out the meaning of unknown words using context, etymology, morphology, compound patterns and other qualities such as onomatopoeia;
17 understand and have the terminology to describe the role of word classes, e.g. preposition, auxiliary verb;
18 understand and use correctly terms of qualification e.g. fully, slightly, similarly, mostly, and comparison, e.g. less, fewer, more, most, ...-er /-est;
19 investigate and apply lexical patterns, e.g. adding -ify to an adjective to create a verb;
20 expand the range of link words and phrases used to signpost texts, including links of time (then, later, meanwhile) and cause (so, because, since);
21 read accurately, and use correctly, vocabulary which relates to key concepts in each subject, distinguishing between everyday uses of words and their subject specific use, e.g. energy, resistance;
22 draw links between words in different languages, e.g. Haus - house; femme - feminine.
10 extend the range of prepositions and connectives used to indicate purpose, e.g. in order to, so that, or express reservations, e.g. although, unless, if;
11 appreciate the impact of figurative language in texts;
12 recognise how the degree of formality influences word choice;
13 understand the implications when a word is in quotation marks or is used ironically;
14 collect and comment on examples of language change, e.g. new words associated with electronic communication and ICT.
7 review and develop their ability to:
8 understand and use key terms that help to describe and analyse language, e.g. word class, noun phrase, subordinate clause, syntax, conditional;
9 appreciate the precise meaning of specialist vocabulary for each school subject, and use specialist terms aptly in their own writing;
16 weigh different viewpoints and present a balanced analysis of an event or issue, e.g. an environmental issue or historical investigation;
17 integrate evidence into writing to support analysis or conclusions, e.g. data, quotation;
18 write a critical review of a substantial text, taking account of the context in which it was written and the likely impact on its intended readers.
18 identify criteria for evaluating a particular situation, object or event, present findings fairly and give a personal view;
19 write reflectively about a text, taking account of the needs of others who might read it.
5 develop the use of commentary and description in narrative, e.g. by addressing the reader directly;
6 experiment with figurative language in conveying a sense of character and setting;
7 experiment with different language choices to imply meaning and to establish the tone of a piece, e.g. ironic, indignant;
8 develop an imaginative or unusual treatment of familiar material or established conventions, e.g. updating traditional tales;
9 experiment with presenting similar material in different forms and styles of poetry;
5 structure a story with an arresting opening, a developing plot, a complication, a crisis and a satisfying resolution;
6 portray character, directly and indirectly, through description, dialogue and action;
7 use a range of narrative devices to involve the reader, e.g. withholding information;
8 experiment with the visual and sound effects of language, including the use of imagery, alliteration, rhythm and rhyme;
9 make links between their reading of fiction, plays and poetry and the choices they make as writers;
10 organise texts in ways appropriate to their content, e.g. by chronology, priority, comparison, and signpost this clearly to the reader;
11 select and present information using detail, example, diagram and illustration as appropriate;
12 develop ideas and lines of thinking in continuous text and explain a process logically, highlighting the links between cause and effect;
13 give instructions and directions which are specific, easy to follow and clearly sequenced;
14 describe an object, person or setting in a way that includes relevant details and is accurate and evocative;
10 organise and present information, selecting and synthesising appropriate material and guiding the reader clearly through the text, e.g. a technological process, an information leaflet;
11 explain complex ideas and information clearly, e.g. defining principles, explaining a scientific process;
12 describe an event, process or situation, using language with an appropriate degree of formality, e.g. a school prospectus;
15 express a personal view, adding persuasive emphasis to key points, e.g. by reiteration, exaggeration, repetition, use of rhetorical questions;
16 find and use different ways to validate an argument, e.g. statistical evidence, exemplification, testimony;
17 write informal advice, anticipating the needs, interests and views of the intended reader, e.g. how to make the most of an opportunity;
13 present a case persuasively, making selective use of evidence, using appropriate rhetorical devices and anticipating responses and objections;
14 develop and signpost arguments in ways that make the logic clear to the reader;
15 give written advice which offers alternatives and takes account of the possible consequences, e.g. money management for young people;
Writing as an aid to memory & understanding
a Information, which maintains the use of the present tense and the third person, organises and links information clearly; incorporates examples
a maintaining a personal record of spelling difficulties and development;
a recognise links between words related by word families and roots;
a recognising and using subordinate clauses;
b Recount, maintains the use of past tense, clear chronology and temporal connectives;
b applying spelling rules and recognising exceptions;
b exploring the functions of subordinate clauses, e.g. relative clauses such as 'which I bought' or adverbial clauses such as 'having finished his lunch';
b work out the meaning of unknown words using context, syntax, etymology, morphology and other factors;
c Explanation, maintains the use of the present tense and impersonal voice, and links points clearly;
c deploying subordinate clauses in a variety of positions within the sentence;
c understand and explain exactly what words mean in particular contexts;
c using dictionaries and spellcheckers where appropriate;
d Instructions, which are helpfully sequenced and signposted, deploy imperative verbs and provide clear guidance;
e Persuasion, emphasises key points and articulates logical links in the argument;
f Discursive writing, which signposts the organisation of contrasting points and clarifies the viewpoint;
f drawing on word structures, families and derivations;
